awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: Controls on weathering, solute fluxes, and geologic carbon cycling in glacierized catchments
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Anna Bergstrom has been awarded an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to work at Colorado State University to study chemical weathering and its role in biogeochemical cycles on glacierized watersheds. Depending on geologic properties and other characteristics of the watershed, watersheds have the potential to be major contributors to the geologic carbon cycle though consumption or release of carbon dioxide. However, the role of glacierized watersheds in the global carbon cycle is unknown because hydrology and solute flux from these systems is poorly understood. This research will unify hydrologic theory and geochemistry in a novel way to understand the controls on weathering-derived impacts in glacierized watersheds of costal Alaska, an area currently seeing rapid glacier mass loss with very large ecologic and economic implications. This understanding will then be applied to a global dataset to evaluate the role of glacierized watersheds in the global carbon cycle. A series of teaching modules for high schools and undergraduate classes will be designed to introduce students to these watersheds and concepts. The postdoc will also give public talks and collaborate with citizen science projects.


This research brings together two closely related but not fully integrated theories to understand processes driving weathering-derived solute flux and the strength of carbon sink or source from glacierized watersheds. In watershed hydrology, concentration-discharge relationships are used to infer a process understanding of solute generation mechanisms, with little exploration of the solute fate. In geochemical weathering estimates of flux, this knowledge of varying relationships has not been fully integrated into our understanding of solute flux estimates and carbon cycling. Coupling these two approaches is a powerful way to advance our understanding of the role of glacierized watersheds in global biogeochemical cycles, and the dominant controls on chemical weathering rates more generally. This integrated research framework will be developed for the Wolverine Glacier watershed located on the Kenai Peninsula of Southcentral Alaska using continuous water quality monitoring and regular water sampling for solute chemistry. This will then be applied to, and tested with, a global dataset of glacierized watersheds to understand the dominant processes and watershed characteristics determining the magnitude and nature of weathering-derived solute flux. This research will improve our understanding of hydrologic processes within glacierized watersheds and the role of these watersheds in the global carbon cycle and will provide a large publicly available global dataset of solute flux and landscape characteristics from high solute flux watersheds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Glacial streams are unique and not well understood. Glaciers act as a reservoir of water and maintain higher, colder streamflow later in the season relative to their non-glacierized counterparts. In addition, glaciers are a huge erosive force, creating fresh material that may be mobilized, carried by streams, and chemically weathered. Chemical weathering can either sequester or produce carbon dioxide depending on the nature of the material, thus glaciers are important not only to hydrologic and sediment fluxes, but to global cycling of carbon as well. However, studies have not been able to determine if glacial watersheds are net carbon sinks or sources, in part because we do not have information on the chemistry, the stream water source, and seasonal variability in stream flows and chemistry. Further uncertainties in glacial catchment carbon budgets result from changing climate, which is leading to rapidly thinning and retreating glaciers and vegetation cover changing. This research addressed fundamental sources of uncertainty surrounding the role of glaciers in hydrological and biogeochemical cycling, with a major focus in southcentral Alaska.  

 

In this study we collected data from Wolverine and the larger Nellie Juan watersheds in the Kenai Mountains in southcentral Alaska. We found that the climate and the source of water (e.g. rain, snowmelt, glacier melt, and groundwater) strongly controls the magnitude and timing of solute loads (chemical weathering products) exported from these watersheds. Because of this variability, continuous monitoring is needed to accurately quantify fluxes and determine whether a watershed is a net carbon sink or source.  Further, we learned that the relative contribution of groundwater to these streams is higher than expected and variable across landscapes, even in high alpine environments that were previously thought to have very little interaction with groundwater.

 

We explored how stream source water and chemistry changes across elevation and by glacier coverage and found that the proportion of ground water contribution increases at lower elevations and in the winter when other water sources are frozen. Further, geochemical analysis of streams in these watersheds show that dissolved weathering products are from sources that may be net carbon sinks. But the type of bedrock and amount of groundwater contribution to streams may be more strongly controlling the amount and type of chemical weathering products in streams than the glaciers themselves.

 

Finally, we collected a dataset of 14 rivers in South Central Alaska including 7 that we actively monitored to determine how climate and percent glacier cover impact seasonal variability in stream flows and solute fluxes. We found that critical transitions in the hydrologic and geochemical regimes in early spring and late fall that are difficult to measure can bias solute flux estimates. Further, individual hydrologic or climate events, such as a glacier outburst flood or heavy rain event, can dominate characterization of an entire season. This highlights that an individual event can have an equally large if not greater impact than seasonal variability on our estimates of how glaciers are impacting global hydrologic and biogeochemical cycles.

 

Work on the stream chemistry and source water in the Wolverine and Nellie Juan watersheds was primarily carried out by a master’s student under the supervision of the PI. This provided valuable experience and training for both the student and the PI, as an early-career researcher. Both benefitted from the mentorship and research network created through this post-doctoral fellowship. The master’s student has successfully defended her thesis and transitioned to a PhD program at a competitive university. The concepts and knowledge gained from this research have been incorporated into a series of lectures created for three environmental and aqueous geochemistry courses taught across three universities that are publicly available on Youtube.
